WOLLASTON LAKE, Sask. _ Crews worked feverishly at the edge of a high school sports field in northern Saskatchewan on Thursday to try to fend off a forest fire and protect two communities.

Environment officials said the blaze near Wollaston Lake and the Hatchet Lake reserve had swelled to 40 square kilometres _ up from five square kilometres Wednesday morning. It was fuelled by dry conditions in grass, bushes and trees.

''We had consistent 20 kilometre per hour winds, very high temperatures and low humidities. We had what we would consider rank five, which is the highest severity of fire behaviour all day (Wednesday),'' said Steve Roberts, the province's executive director of wildfire management.

The northern flank of the fire was burning at the southernmost edge of the communities _ the high school property. That was the control point where firefighters were holding the line, said Roberts.

''Our focus is around the town _ a small point on a big fire, but it's also our critical priority.''

Roberts said the fire was expanding eastward, away from the communities, and wind was keeping smoke out.

It was good news for Ed Benoanie, acting chief of Hatchet Lake. He was one of about 15 residents who stayed to help with firefighting efforts after everyone else was airlifted out.

''The worst has pretty much passed us now, I think,'' said Benoanie. ''The fire was kind of around us on the reserve and it continued to the north. It's still blazing in the north, but right now the smoke is almost clear.''

Benoanie said there had been fears that homes would be lost.

''(Wednesday) was like a war zone here. It was ground zero just about, but ... right now we're much safer. It's much better ... that's for sure.''

Wollaston Lake is about 840 kilometres north of Saskatoon and can only be reached by air at this time of year.

The fire was first reported to Saskatchewan Environment early Monday evening and was about one square kilometre in size.

Fifteen aircraft lifted out about 240 people Tuesday after an evacuation order came down. But smoke at the airport Wednesday hampered efforts to remove everyone. Those left behind hunkered down in two schools until military aircraft arrived to help.

Provincial fire commissioner Duane McKay said almost everyone _ nearly 1,200 people _ had been airlifted out by Thursday morning.

''The decision to call the military is because this was a very high risk situation, very dynamic and posed serious threat,'' said McKay.

Four Griffon helicopters ferried residents to Points North, on the other side of the lake, on flights that took about 20 minutes. By sunrise, evacuees were being taken to shelters in Saskatoon on the bigger Hercules aircraft, which hold 96 people each.

''They seemed tired for the most part,'' said Capt. Chris Jacobson, who piloted one of the Hercules aircraft. ''I think a lot of them had been up for a lot of hours, but they seemed thankful, grateful and in generally good spirits.''

Saskatchewan Premier Brad Wall thanked everyone involved in the ''difficult and often dangerous task.''

It's not unusual for the province to move people when there are forest fires in northern areas, but it's usually those considered vulnerable to breathing problems from smoke, such as children and elders. McKay said he believed the last time a community was completely evacuated was in 2005 when fire threatened Stoney Rapids.

Lightning has been ruled out as the cause of the fire near Wollaston Lake.

Roberts said the fire was started by human activity, but it's not clear if the action was accidental or intentional. A team of investigators was flown in Thursday afternoon to look at the fire origin site in a forested area near the end of the airstrip, he said.

The Wollaston Lake fire is still considered out of control.

''The worst case scenario was we ended up with fire right in the town site, so that was our goal to prevent that. Most of the active fire component actually bypassed the town, went to the east, while we were working that southern flank,'' said Roberts.

Roberts said the perspective from people on the ground is that fire activity is ''much reduced'' but the threat remains.

''There is still a fire on the edge of town. We still have a fair bit of work to do to secure those lines, but again we're now looking at things like the cooler weather and lower winds to assist us in doing that.''

_ By Jennifer Graham in Regina, with files from CJWW in Saskatoon.

(CP) - Armed Forces Hercules planes from Edmonton are on standby in case a forest fire moving toward the northwestern Ontario community of Big Trout Lake forces more evacuations of its residents today.</p><p>Yesterday about 40 sick and elderly people were taken out.</p><p>Whipped by northwest winds, the fire last night was about five kilometres (three miles) north of Big Trout Lake, which has more than 800 residents.</p><p>Dennis Wilson, a Natural Resources Ministry spokesman in Sioux Lookout, said the blaze which started Tuesday "has flames 20 metres (65 feet) high. There's not much you can do with a fire that intense and rapid moving."</p><p>The fire covers 37 square kilometres (14 square miles), he said.</p><p>Wilson said he didn't expect evacuation to Dryden and Red Lake would be necessary before daybreak.</p><p>Residents from about 30 houses on the shore of the lake have been moved to the main community on Post Island, about 600 kilometres (360 miles) north of Thunder Bay.</p><p>Aircraft, boats and helicopters were also prepared to evacuate 320 residents of Sachigo Lake and 12 in Pontask Lake from the path of another rapidly moving fire.</p><p>That blaze, apparently started by lightning Sunday, was about five kilometres north of Sachigo Lake yesterday. The two communities are about 620 kilometres (372 miles) northwest of Thunder Bay.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) - Cool weather Friday put a damper on a brush fire that had threatened a sawmill and pulp mill in northwestern Saskatchewan. Hot, dry winds Thursday sent flames roaring into the yard of the NorSask sawmill, about eight kilometres east of Meadow Lake, where they engulfed about $2 million worth of wood. There were fears the blaze would spread to the $350-million Millar Western pulp mill less than two kilometres down the road. But Duncan Campbell, spokesman for the Saskatchewan forest fire management centre, said Friday cooler weather and overcast skies helped save the day. "It's being held today,'' Campbell said. "The mill is in very little danger now.'' Friday morning, the blaze was burning about 200 metres from the sawmill. The day before, the flames had jumped a firebreak and ignited the log pile at the mill. "It started some miles away and the wind just jumped it right in,'' said Ian Buchanan, the sawmill's sales manager. "It ignited the logs stacked in the yard … they've pretty much been consumed.'' RCMP closed part of the highway leading into Meadow Lake Thursday and evacuated several homes near the fire, which burned a total of about 400 hectares of private land. Campbell said the fire was caused by a someone clearing stubble and was spread by winds gusting up to 70 kilometres an hour. Firefighters, assisted by six provincial air tankers, bombarded the fire with retardant to contain the blaze.</p><p>Campbell said the flames will likely take some time to douse completely in the huge piles of logs near the sawmill. "It's just like charcoal. "There's about 50,000 cubic metres of logs in there - it'll be smouldering and burning for a while.'' The weekend forecast for the area called for rain. Campbell said the northern Saskatchewan forest will be a tinderbox this summer, the result of below-average rain and snow and five years of low water levels. "It's very dry - as dry as it's been since 1911,'' he said. "We're in pretty tough shape.'' He said there have already been 136 fires in the northern half of the province this year, nearly double the usual number. Another fire that broke out Wednesday near Dillon, Sask., 200 kilometres further north, has destroyed about 170 hectares of forest. About 25 people were evacuated from the nearby Indian reserve Thursday, until the blaze was brought under control.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) - A forest fire that once threatened Penticton homes continued to burn east of the city today, spreading at a rate of about 100 hectares a day.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire has swept through 400 hectares, an area about two square kilometres, since it started Wednesday in Ellis Creek Canyon near this Okanagan city 200 kilometres east of Vancouver.</p><p>"We're not classifying it as under control but we certainly made good progress yesterday,'' said Wendy Stewart, B.C. Forest Service spokeswoman.</p><p>"While the fire grew we were able to get out ahead of it and we have a guard in.''</p><p>More crew members were added to the fireline today with 170 people working on it in searing heat, up from 131 people Friday.</p><p>Fire crews contained the fire on its north and west flanks, areas bordering Penticton where a subdivision had been threatened as flames got to within a few hundred metres and residents prepared to flee.</p><p>Forecast winds didn't materialize, giving firefighters an edge they needed to set up guards in its path.</p><p>A large cloud of smoke crowned the hills east of Skaha Lake south of Penticton but the smoke has drifted clear of the city.</p><p>Firefighters were also busy near the Fraser Canyon community of Boston Bar, battling a forest fire that broke out late Friday afternoon.</p><p>Some had to be diverted to fight an unrelated blaze that broke out in the log yard of J. S. Marie.</p><p>A provincial fire response team has already taken over a fire near Cold Lake, Alta., he said this morning.</p><p>A total of 23 fire crews - each with four people - are expected to be in Alberta by Tuesday to help firefighters there. Four water bombers also are being sent to Alberta. As well, equipment such as hoses, shovels, tents and pumps is being sent to Saskatchewan.</p><p>"Depending on the next few days in Ontario we may be able to free up more,'' Thomas said.</p><p>More than 1,000 firefighters have been battling blazes in Northern Ontario for the last month.</p><p>The ministry declared a restricted fire zone May 8 for vast portions of Northern Ontario because of the extremely dry conditions.</p><p>Almost 30 millimetres of rain fell in the Sault Ste. Marie area overnight Saturday, Environment Canada reported.</p><p>The heavy downpour brought the monthly total for May to 44 millimetres - well below the normal level of 69.</p><p>In North Bay, the storm dumped 30.3 millimetres of rain on the city and as much as 70 millimetres in outlying areas.</p><p>"Finally, we get a breather,'' said Lynn Wissler, a forest fire technician with the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources in North Bay.</p><p>"We've pulled all but two crews out of the bush. Now, we'll be able to give some of our people a rest.''</p><p>He also said that because there was lightning, there is always the possibility that new fires might surface after smouldering underground for several days. (Sault Star, North Bay Nugget)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier "But when we took off, we could see a wall of flame and I thought to myself, "This may be goodbye to Lynn Lake.' "</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>About 800 residents fled in the dead of night Wednesday as the violent red glow of flames crept to within five km of the community.</p><p>They fled by road and air 100 km southeast to Leaf Rapids and 225 km southeast to Thompson after the fire knocked out the town's electricity.</p><p>Three helicopters, five waterbombers, four bulldozers and 100 people were trying to get a handle on the fire, which covered 18,000 hectares - as big as 280 average-size golf courses.</p><p>Tired, thankful, and in some cases angry and bewildered, many evacuees replayed the night and days before in their heads as they wrestled with their newfound refugee status Thursday.</p><p>One woman said she wished she could have saved a bed of tomatoes.</p><p>"As we drove down the road, I felt more and more guilty that I hadn't protected the plants from the cold," the woman said. "Then I remembered the real problem was the heat."</p><p>Bonner and her husband boarded a Thompson-bound jet Wednesday night with their four children. She was worried about $300 worth of meat and perishable food left in their refrigerator and freezer.</p><p>"I had about a month's stuff stored up," Bonner said.</p><p>Joseph Colomb, who was transferred with his family to a Thompson elementary school, said he felt if the province had done its job, nothing - neither tomatoes nor meat - would have been left behind.</p><p>He said the fire was allowed to burn unchallenged for 12 days before firefighters were ordered to battle the blaze three days ago.</p><p>And by then it was too late.</p><p>"For some reason they thought it was OK to let it burn," Colomb, said in a phone interview. "That's stupid."</p><p>But Harlan Mushumanski, a spokesman for Manitoba's Emergency Measures Organization, said the Department of Natural Resources was trying to let the fire burn itself out - a standard procedure.</p><p>"The resources were not really at risk, and in the early stages there was no immediate risk to the town," he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier "We are also dealing with propane tanks that have been impinged."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>The Canadian Press</p></bodyText></section><p>The 3,000 residents who are being allowed to return home after fleeing the Strawberry Hill fire a week ago are from several small villages as well as rural areas northeast of Kamloops.</p><p>Some of the remaining 3,500 evacuees from the most damaging wildfire in British Columbia this summer said they are disappointed they are going to be the last residents able to go home.</p><p>"It's hard, but I don't want to go back if it's unsafe," said Dianne Richards, a resident of Barriere, 50 kilometres north of Kamloops.</p><p>Residents from the area where the fire now has grown to 181 square kilometres, have been on a roller-coaster since Wednesday, when officials said it could be weeks before it was safe enough for them to return.</p><p>After touring the region by air on Thursday, B.C. Forests Minister Mike de Jong said all evacuees could go back within 24 hours if was deemed safe.</p><p>An official at an area emergency operations centre said yesterday that politicians wanted to expedite the return of evacuees because they were sensitive to the residents' plight.</p><p>"They are all trying to get the suffering minimized of people as best they can but not to compromise safety," said John Smith, director of the Thompson-Nicola Regional District's emergency operations centre.</p><p>But B.C. forest officials said the Barriere-McLure fire is still far too dangerous for residents to return.</p><p>"We have hundreds of miles of control lines that need to be established," said Kevin Matuga, an information officer for B.C. Forest Service.</p><p>Damage assessment to properties in the Kamloops-area fires is $8.2 million so far. It doesn't include a sawmill, other businesses and hundreds of gutted vehicles.</p><p>The Tolko mill in the village of Louis Creek employed about 200 people.</p><p>Smith said yesterday he had no new information on a re-entry plan for the Barriere-McLure area.</p><p>This fire was 20 per cent contained, said Matuga while the Strawberry Hill blaze was 90 per cent contained.</p><p>The Cedar Hills fire is now totally contained behind fire guards, he said.</p><p>The forest service said there were 640 fires burning as of Thursday night, 445 of them caused by lightning.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5SX4-MMD1-JDH3-G0WG-00000-00Muskoka's total fire ban lifted as danger rating moves from extreme to high2018-06-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:27ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Muskoka's total fire ban lifted as danger rating moves from extreme to high

MUSKOKA - (UPDATE: 10:13 a.m., Wednesday, July 25) After just shy of three weeks under a complete fire ban, the Muskoka Fire Danger Rating is now set at high, according to Gravenhurst Fire Department.

The #Muskoka forest fire danger rating is now set at "HIGH" ... While the total fire ban has been lifted, please remember that daytime burning is still prohibited.

Don't get complacent folks, that little bit of rain we received won't have long-lasting effects pic.twitter.com/8RxP3hIle4 - GravenhurstFIRE (@GravenhurstFIRE) July 25, 2018

Muskoka had been under an extreme fire danger rating, meaning a complete fire ban, since Thursday, July 5.

Daytime burning is not permitted in a high rating. There are also size limits, clearance requirements, provisions respecting fire control measures you must have in place as well as other provisions under the by-law which you must be aware of if you decide to burn. In a high rating, avoid campfires, even for cooking and warmth if possible. A high fire danger rating is serious. Use extreme caution.

For more information on what this means in your municipality, check local bylaws: Bracebridge, Gravenhurst, Huntsville, Muskoka Lakes, Lake of Bays, Georgian Bay. Call Toll Free 1-877-847-1577 for the up-to-date Muskoka Fire Danger Rating.

The Muskoka Fire Danger Rating is determined using the Fire Weather Index (FWI), an internationally used method for determining the risk of fires in open air. It uses factors such as the relative humidity, temperature, previous 24-hour rain amount, wind directions and wind speed in combination with the forest fuel type and loads to determine the risk of the forest to certain fire types. From this calculation the Forest Fire Danger Rating is made in consultation with the fire chiefs of the six area municipalities and the Ministry of Natural Resources.

(CP) - About 150 people were forced from their remote Northern Ontario homes early Thursday after a forest fire led to the evacuation of the town of Peawanuk.</p><p>While forest fires in the Prairies and B.C. appear to stabilize, two Hercules aircraft were called in to help airlift people from the community on Hudson's Bay to Timmins - a 2 1/2 hour flight away.</p><p>-BODY- Some 40 people refused to leave town and decided to fight the flames instead.</p><p>It's expected it will take about three days for the area to clear.</p><p>"I'm thinking this fire is in good shape and could see . . . . people being back in their community by the weekend,'' said Dan Johnson, the Ministry of Natural Resources fire technician called in to handle the fire.</p><p>Some 15 firefighters were still trying to get the fire under control Thursday afternoon.</p><p>"Crews are making excellent progress,'' said Johnson. "The weather and weather forecast has really assisted us in our effort.''</p><p>Johnson said some nine millimetres of rain fell Wednesday night.</p><p>The fire spread to 100 hectares and crept to within a kilometre of the town on the Weenuska First Nation reserve when the acting chief declared an emergency.</p><p>Johnson said the fire was still within a kilometre of Peawanuk on Thursday afternoon but felt there was no danger of it spreading further due to the direction of the winds.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata However, they won't speak out publicly, fearing their jobs could be affected, he said.</p><p>"They've seen these before (internal inquiries),'' Brohman said. "There's no political will to do anything.</p><p>"It has to be a public inquiry where employees could speak freely. All of these unionized employees wouldn't have confidence in the department's ability to investigate itself.''</p><p>One employee said the Yukon's forest fire fighting program has "gone from being the best in Canada three years ago to a Gong Show,'' Brohman said.</p><p>The dismantling of the forest fire program began about two years ago, Brohman said. Positions such as aerial observer jobs and resources were cut and never replaced, he added.</p><p>"Fire detection was reduced by 30 per cent in watch towers, for example,'' he said.</p><p>Employees' concerns include complaints that officials ignored a suggestion to bring in an aerial tanker against the big Carmacks-area fire until it was too late. There were also reports of skimping on the use of fire retardant, he said.</p><p>Indian and Northern Affairs decided recently to have a formal review of some of this summer's larger fires, Lois Craig, the department's acting regional director-general, said Wednesday.</p><p>"I didn't use the word internal,'' she said. "We haven't decided that yet. It may be an independent review.''</p><p>No one has contacted the department directly to ask for a public inquiry, she added. The union's views have come through only via the media.</p><p>A formal review may examine a variety of factors, such as concerns expressed by the Selkirk First Nation about the timing of central Yukon firefighting activities, procedures, and costs, she said.</p><p>The 132 fires so far this year have cost $3.5 million to date, said department spokesman Rod Raycroft. It cost $2.7 million to fight 150 fires last year.</p><p>McLaughlin, meanwhile, supports the union's calls for an inquiry, but says they're not necessarily to be taken as a criticism of the department's management.</p><p>"I think it's time we had a public inquiry partly because resources have been cut back,'' she said Wednesday from Dawson City.</p><p>"It's not just this year. This has been going on for a few years and a lot of questions have been building up.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Positions such as aerial observer jobs and resources were cut and never replaced, he added.</p><p>"Fire detection was reduced by 30 per cent in watch towers, for example,'' he said.</p><p>Employees' concerns include complaints that officials ignored a suggestion to bring in an aerial tanker against the big Carmacks-area fire until it was too late. There were also reports of skimping on the use of fire retardant, he said.</p><p>Indian and Northern Affairs decided recently to have a formal review of some of this summer's larger fires, Lois Craig, the department's acting regional director-general, said Wednesday.</p><p>"I didn't use the word internal,'' she said. "We haven't decided that yet. It may be an independent review.''</p><p>No one has contacted the department directly to ask for a public inquiry, she added. The union's views have come through only via the media.</p><p>A formal review may examine a variety of factors, such as concerns expressed by the Selkirk First Nation about the timing of central Yukon firefighting activities, procedures, and costs, she said.</p><p>The 132 fires so far this year have cost $3.5 million to date, said department spokesman Rod Raycroft. It cost $2.7 million to fight 150 fires last year.</p><p>McLaughlin, meanwhile, supports the union's calls for an inquiry, but says they're not necessarily to be taken as a criticism of the department's management.</p><p>"I think it's time we had a public inquiry partly because resources have been cut back,'' she said Wednesday from Dawson City.</p><p>"It's not just this year. This has been going on for a few years and a lot of questions have been building up.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5XW2-SH51-DY91-K4FN-00000-00Canada sends more firefighters to battle blazes2019-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:27ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A2Canada sends more firefighters to battle blazesThe Canadian PressWINNIPEG

Firefighters from across Canada are on their way to Australia to bolster Canadians already assisting the country in the battle against devastating wildfires.

Stephen Tulle, duty officer with the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, says a group of 15 set out for Queensland Monday, while another group of 21 will fly out later in the week.

He says the contingent of Canadian wildfire specialists stationed in Queensland and New South Wales will reach 87 by Saturday.

This is the first time that Canada has sent firefighters to Australia, although Tulle says crews from Down Under have visited and were vital in helping British Columbia handle widespread wildfires in 2017 and 2018.

The Canadian contingent is made up of volunteers from B.C., Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec, Newfoundland and Labrador, Yukon and Parks Canada.

The Australian wildfires have killed 10 people and destroyed 1,000 homes across the country in the past few months.

Tulle says the Canadians will primarily be performing fire-manager duties, related to command, planning, logistics and aviation management.

Canadian firefighters will spend about six weeks in Australia and Tulle said Canada will continue to send crews as long as volunteers can be found, and Australia is requesting help.

Six bulldozers and 50 firefighters defended the hamlet's southern limits Saturday as water bombers hammered back the flames enough for the evacuation order to be lifted later in the afternoon.</p><p>Rick Strickland, provincial fire information officer, said several of the residents returned after the winds died down and scattered showers drifted over the fire.</p><p>A fireguard has been established around the perimeter of the town and a municipal fire truck waited on standby to protect the buildings in the community.</p><p>Firefighters are also working to protect another 12 unoccupied summer cottages in the area.</p><p>Chisholm is on the northern boundary of the 120 square kilometre fire that is now under attack from 200 firefighters and a fleet of helicopters, planes and heavy equipment.</p><p>Thirteen residents of Flatbush, about 20 km to the south, remain on evacuation alert, but winds blowing out of the east Saturday have given them some respite.</p><p>"The wind is going southwest,'' said Strickland. "It is moving the fire away from Chisholm and the Flatbush area, but who knows what is going to happen tomorrow.''</p><p>About 30 people evacuated from farms north of Flatbush Friday had earlier been allowed to return to their homes, but remain on evacuation alert.</p><p>"We're dealing with a fire and conditions that could change at a moment's notice,'' said Barb Toker, an Alberta fire spokeswoman at the scene. "While we're doing good work out here right now, we're taking every precaution.''</p><p>She said the Chisholm fire was the largest fire in Alberta this year.</p><p>Meanwhile, Transport Canada investigators were able to return on Saturday to the scene of a plane crash that killed two people who had been helping fight another fire Friday.</p><p>RCMP removed the bodies of the pilot and passenger of a forest fire spotter plane that crashed on the edge of fire burning northeast of Red Earth Creek, but had to evacuate the area when the fire came within a half kilometre.</p><p>RCMP Cst. Cliff Brennan said investigators are still having difficulty assessing the crash site due to adverse weather conditions. Police said smoke had reduced visibility in the area.</p><p>The names of the victims haven't been released.</p><p>The Cessna went down in dense forest in a hilly area.</p><p>Strickland said the passenger in the aircraft was a veteran air attack officer who was mapping out a strategy for water bombers to attack the lightning-caused fire.</p><p>"He went up there to do an initial attack on that fire,'' he said. "It is an unfortunate situation.''</p><p>Strickland said grief counsellors have been sent in to help employees and family deal with the situation.</p><p>"Certainly there's a number of individuals that are affected by this,'' he said.</p><p>Strickland said the deaths are the first involving Alberta firefighters since a firefighter died fighting a blaze near Mariana Lake, south of Fort McMurray, in May, 1995.</p><p>Meanwhile, 488 firefighters continued to fight 18 fires in the province after one of the driest winters in Alberta history. Five fires, including the Chisholm fire, continued to burn out of control Saturday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) _ Nova Scotia turned to its neighbour for water-bomber help in fighting a forest fire near the provincial border Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It's right up in the tops of the trees, and that makes it easy for it to jump,'' said Maureen Horne, assistant duty officer at the Shubenacadie Fire Centre.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>It jumped a main power line.''</p><p>The two-hectare blaze was burning out of control in the Fort Lawrence area. Fire officials were alerted by a 911 caller at about 1:45 p.m.</p><p>Horne said no homes or businesses needed to be evacuated. Officials don't know how the fire started.</p><p>Horne said two Natural Resources Department helicopters were sent to battle the fire. And we also have some water bombers that are coming in from New Brunswick.''</p><p>Natural Resources Minister Ernie Fage said this week the ban on open fires and travel in Nova Scotia's woods is still in effect.</p><p>That means both bans, which may be imposed until the end of September, affects campers and hikers over the Labour Day weekend.</p><p>The province has already exhausted its $3.5-million forest-firefighting budget, and the risk of more scorched woods hasn't diminished.</p><p> As soon as we are confident with a reduction in risk due to increased rainfall, Natural Resources will quickly lift the bans,'' Fage said.</p><p>(Halifax Chronicle-Herald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata While no property was threatened, city official Bob McKinnon said some cottage owners along Hidden Lake could soon face an evacuation alert.</p><p>Because of the smoke, the Yellowknife airport remained open only to airplanes flying on instruments.</p><p>A pair of DC-4 airplanes had laid down a strip of retardant about 30 kilometres from the city, said Dave Purchase of the N.W.T.'s Forestry Management Division. Fire crews were heading in to start back burns to rob the fire of fuel.</p><p>"We think we'll get a handle on it with the lines we're putting down,'' said Purchase. "The winds seem to switching in our favor, starting to blow out of the south.''</p><p>The winds, at about 15 kilometres Sunday, had been blowing from the northeast.</p><p>Ash and smoke tainted the town's air and cut visibility to about a kilometre, said McKinnon.</p><p>"There's no blue sky. We can smell it.''</p><p>He downplayed any danger of the fire travelling through to Yellowknife.</p><p>"There's lots of lakes up here,'' he said.</p><p>Resources on the fire include 50 firefighters, two DC-4s dropping retardant and four water bombers, said Purchase. Another 50 firefighters remain in reserve.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier A2</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Penticton homes evacuated as forest fire nears suburbs</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>VANCOUVER PROVINCE</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>VANCOUVERFOREST FIRE PENTICTION BRITISH COLUMBIA</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Hundreds of Penticton residents fled their homes last night as a forest fire raged out of control on the edge of town.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The wind-whipped blaze burned 1 kilometre from Penticton Regional Hospital as patients and staff waited anxiously to hear if they'd be leaving.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Those already evacuated live in the northeast section of this town of 27,000 at the south end of Okanagan Lake, about 250 kilometres east of Vancouver.</p><p>Some had lost their homes by late last night.</p><p>"We are not winning at the moment," admitted forest service spokesman John Rempel.</p><p>Winds hampered the efforts of about 200 firefighters.</p><p>Crews were pulled back to water down homes in the fire's path and spread retardant.</p><p>More than 500 people from several subdivisions had been moved. Many spent the night with friends or slept on cots in a gym at the Penticton Community Centre.</p><p>A number of homes were reported burned in the Carmi subdivision, a neighborhood about 4 kilometres from downtown.</p><p>"There's no stopping it," said Janet Scott, who fled her home early yesterday. "There is no water supply up here and no fire hydrants."</p><p>But, "There's no suggestion at all that that's even a possibility, basically because there's nothing to allow the fire to continue to spread in the city," Roger Venables of the Penticton Forest District said.</p><p>The six-day fire had been in retreat, but yesterday the wind shifted. The blaze leaped a containment barrier and grew from 500 to 1,700 hectares.</p><p>"A finger of fire escaped last night," said Rempel. "We were very confident about the barrier. urn:contentItem:5T49-TVW1-F105-652V-00000-00Smoke altering daily habits2018-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:27ZLexisNexisOPINIONSmoke altering daily habits

From the minute I woke up this morning I could tell forest fire smoke would be a problem today. Even with most of my windows closed overnight, walking into the kitchen was akin to checking on a working smokehouse. I could taste it.

I've lived through forest fire smoke so thick the sun was bloody orange like the yoke in a pullet hen's first eggs, but here the sun is blocked behind Copper Mountain until 10:30 a.m. or so.

After breakfast I leashed the dogs and set out to walk before the temperature climbed any higher. Looking south along the street a blue curtain closed the far end, and on both the north and east sides a blue tinge obscured the mountains.

For a moment I debated whether or not to continue our walk, after all the advisories warning seniors or others with breathing problems to stay indoors and above all not over exert themselves in physical activity.

But I kept walking, knowing how much our daily outing means to both the dogs and myself. They look forward to coming home to a cold drink of water followed by a three or four hour nap in a shady spot. My plan in this hot weather, with or without forest fire smoke, is to loaf the day away watching TV newscasts and commentaries.

As a concession, I chose a slightly shorter route just in case. By the time we had gone less than three blocks I began to feel slightly dizzy. My eyesight grew fuzzy. Stepping between two trees to leave the open path for a narrow way through bush I hugged one tree to steady myself so I wouldn't scrape my arm on rough bark.

The atmosphere became slightly less smoky as we turned north, the mountains ahead more sharply outlined. Nonetheless when we reached our regular rest stop — a low pile of 3 x 12 planks Highways uses to shore up bridges during heavy spring runoff — roughly one third of the total trail distance, I was eager to sit down as were the dogs. During normal weather, we walk half that 60 minute trail with only two sit-downs. Not today. We took several extra rests including one where we sprawled on the grass of Copper Mountain's upper playing field. The clipped grass felt cool, and the ridge offered a breeze absent on the remainder of the trail where it is enclosed by tall trees, low shrubbery, and hip high grasses and tansy.

Vegetation of all kinds show signs of prolonged stress whether from strictly water deprivation and too much heat or smoke as well. Underfoot dry curled leaves crackle. Alder are as naked as they usually become only in late September. Tansy looks wizened, blossoms shrunken. I'd venture not a single wild strawberry grew this summer. And everywhere bush is silent – no little birds singing, even few crows or ravens since their fledglings graduated to unpopulated crown land.

By some fluke, the two crows who hatched close by are hanging around as though this is their preferred home turf. I call them The Twins. They sit side by side on the hydro wire, sidle along the shed ridgepole one after the other, together invade my yard to ream any tidbits my dogs have left on their beef bones, and generally stay near each other. They say little. Come winter, I can see feeding them for the pleasure of observing their behaviour.

How much wildlife have we lost to our forest fires?

"There's accommodations … cots and other things there."</p><p>Rejman said the evacuation of about 25 acreages along the Adanac Road and in east Hillcrest along the river was mandatory.</p><p>"We had our fire department go to every home and tell people they had to leave," he said.</p><p>"We've closed the road there and it's now manned so nobody can go up that road. For the rest of Hillcrest, we had members of other fire departments going door to door, telling them about the one-hour alert."</p><p>Rejman said there is concern that homes in the area could be destroyed.</p><p>There is also concern that part of the fire is burning south of the larger, nearby community of Blairmore.</p><p>Patrick Loewen, provincial wildfire information officer, said the blaze had grown to 70 square kilometres by yesterday morning - doubling in size from the night before.</p><p>Loewen said the fire was out of control and the situation was not looking good due to winds, high temperatures and dry conditions.</p><p>About 300 people fighting the blaze and more were on the way, he added.</p><p>Townspeople started watching the sky Saturday, as Mayor John Irwin Creek Mercantile.</p><p>"It's kind of like a war zone - it's worrisome to say the least."</p><p>At times and at its top speed, the fire has been estimated to move at 27 metres a minute, easily capable of outpacing a human, especially on the steep terrain.</p><p>"It's certainly one of the worst I've been on in Alberta," said incident commander Andy Gesner.</p><p>Livestock was being moved to nearby farms and work vehicles to nearby towns.</p><p>A fire just as big was continuing to burn in Glacier National Park in Montana, about 100 kilometres south.</p><p>Firefighters were also fighting a number of blazes across British Columbia.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Campers are permitted cooking fires in portable stoves or charcoal burners.</p><p>Near the large fire, known as Thunder Bay 71, there are seven roads leading into the 600 cottages and more than a half-dozen commercial camps on the lake south of the Trans-Canada Highway at Upsala.</p><p>Water bombers</p><p>Two water bombers borrowed from Quebec and 21 ground crews are battling the fire.</p><p>It has already destroyed 3,000 cords of cut wood belonging to Great Lakes Forest Products and a large quantity of hose and portable pumps abandoned when crews had to flee the flames fanned by high winds on Wednesday.</p><p>But portable sprinklers set up around the only group of cottages threatened so far saved the buildings, said Felix Barbetti, an information officer in the Thunder Bay office.</p><p>Cooler weather, low winds, high humidity and rain showers forecast for later today could help firefighters throughout the north, he said.</p><p>There were 30 new fires reported yesterday in Ontario, officials said, bringing the total of active fires to 90.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source Welcome to Lake Flashback. Reporter Lexi Bainas has been c ombing through old newspapers with the assistance of the Kaatza Station Museum and Archives so we can jog your memory, give you that nostalgic feeling, or just a chuckle, as we take a look at what was making headlines this week around Cowichan Lake in years gone by.

This week around the Cowichan Lake...

10 years ago:

The dream of bringing a frequent and affordable commuter rail service to the Cowichan Valley has hardly hit the end of the tracks, readers of the Lake Cowichan Gazette read on April 11, 2007.

"Even though the Malahat Corridor Study eliminated rail as an option to improve the stretch of highway, the ghost is not gone," the main story said. "Jack Peake, Cowichan Valley Regional District board chair [and Island Corridor Foundation co-chair], is very optimistic that a reliable and affordable rail service will be brought to the Valley in the foreseeable future. Right now, members of the Island Corridor Foundation are looking at ways to provide a rail service that would run from Nanaimo to Victoria several times a day.

"At the end of the day, if both organizations like what we see, we'll be implementing that service within the next year," said Peake.

For him, "a rail service would be the "simplest, easiest" way to address the issue. Almost every day, he hears from people interested in seeing a rail service here. 'It's an incremental service,' he said. 'This isn't a big cost.'"

25 years ago:

"Keep your eyes on the sky" warned The Lake News of April 8, 1992.

The fear was that "Fire season could be early this year".

There was reason for concern, too, according to the story.

"'We need a good rainfall to combat the hazard,'" said D. J. Eastman, operations manager of the Duncan Forest District..." Last Friday, the Duncan office had already responded to the 'prescribed' slash fire carried out the previous week by Macmillan Bloedel, which had re-ignited.

"According to Eastman, charcoal had caused further burning in the 80 hectare area, fanned by strong winds. At about the same time, a water bomber had been dispatched to a fire on Canadian Forest Products property. A Lake News reader reported that a water bomber had scooped up water in front of her house to douse the fire."

40 years ago:

"Youbou vigilantes confront bikers, shotgun blast wounds man" was the eye-catching headline in the April 13, 1977 issue of The Lake News .

According to reporter Tony Kant, "A police spokesman said the man was shot in the foot during an alteraction about 5:30 a.m. Sunday. The shooting victim was with a group of 12 members of a bike club attending a party... The Lake News learned from an observer who wished to remain anonymous, a vigilante group entered the house at the request of someone who feared the gang was assaulting and attempting to rape a local female resident who had gone into the house earlier. The observer said a group of five 'concerned citizens' went to the house with shotguns and rifles to confront the motorcycle gang. By the time the vigilante group got to the house, members of the motorcycle club were the only remaining occupants. According to the spokesman, an altercation developed between one of the vigilantes and a motorcycle gang member and a gun discharged."

PINNACLE RENEWABLE HOLDINGS INC ("PL-T") - Provides Update on B.C. Forest Fires and its Operations

Pinnacle Renewable Holdings Inc. ("Pinnacle" or the "Company") today provided an update on its operations in British Columbia amid the current high level of forest fire activity in the province. B.C. Wildfire Services estimates there are currently approximately 600 active wildfires in the province, versus approximately 150 at this time last year. The Company reports that none of its facilities are currently under immediate threat of encroachment from wildfires, however there are wildfires burning in the proximity of some of its production facilities.

With its long operating history in British Columbia, Pinnacle has extensive experience in managing its operations during seasonal forest fire periods and puts the safety of its employees first and foremost. The Company is closely monitoring the current wildfires in the proximity of its facilities and will provide timely updates on any developments that could impact its operations. In the event of an evacuation or required temporary closure of a facility due to forest fire encroachment, Pinnacle is experienced in managing its network of facilities to ensure customer shipments.

"We are adept at managing our network of facilities to adjust for potential temporary operational disruptions. We had to close our Williams Lake production facility for 24 days last year during July and August due to a forest fire and no customer shipments were missed. Our network of facilities was able to absorb this temporary closure and make up the production elsewhere," said Vaughan Bassett, Senior Vice President, Sales and Logistics.

About Pinnacle

Pinnacle is a rapidly growing industrial wood pellet manufacturer and distributor and the third largest producer in the world. The Company produces renewable fuel for electricity generation in the form of industrial wood pellets, which are used by global utilities and large-scale power generators to produce renewable and reliable baseload power. Pinnacle is a trusted supplier to its customers, who require reliable, high quality fuel supply to maximize utilization of their facilities. Pinnacle takes pride in its industry leading safety practices. The Company operates seven industrial wood pellet production facilities in western Canada, a port terminal in Prince Rupert, B.C., and currently has a new production facility under construction in Smithers, B.C. Pinnacle has entered into long-term take-or-pay contracts with utilities in the U.K., Europe and Asia that represent 109% of its production capacity through 2021 and nearly 101% of its production capacity through 2026.

urn:contentItem:5GJ0-MDN1-F197-537K-00000-00Canoeists encounter forest fire in cross-country trip2015-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:27ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Canoeists encounter forest fire in cross-country trip

SASKATCHEWAN - When Celine and Gerry Daoust left Alberta in early May, forest fires was the last thing on their mind.

After taking a year and a half to prepare themselves financially and mentally for the canoe trip of a lifetime, the couple, self dubbed the Canadian Voyageur, set sail with their 11-year-old Pomeranian, PomPom, towards Quebec. But two and a half months into their trip tested their strength and the trip had to be cut short.

"We were close to Cumberland House, past [Prince Albert]. We spent ten days in the smoke," Celine said. "We waited five days for evacuation."

The Mattawa natives were camping in Fort Carlton, in Saskatchewan, when they woke up one morning and noticed a disturbance in the atmosphere.

"The first morning, when we woke up, the sun was red," Celine said. "We thought it was just fog. Then we were told that 100 kilometres north of [Prince Albert] were forest fires but all safe."

"Every day, it got worse and worse to the point where we could not navigate anymore," she said. "We could not see which way the river was going, we could not see around the islands, and that got us into a lot of trouble. We were taking the wrong way, we would end up in a closed channel. We would have to portage, and we have like 500 pounds of gear."

"It just keep getting worse and worse and worse," she said. "We would have breathing issues. It started effecting our health big time, and not to mention the scariness of it."

"We were feeling sick, we were feeling afraid, we were feeling trapped," she said. "And it was so hot and humid, and where we were camped, we couldn't really move to somewhere else. It was incredibly hot, it was tick infested."

Everyday proved to be a guessing game, Celine said.

"It was like an emergency but it was an emergency waiting to happen," she said. "From one day to the next, you didn't know which way the wind would blow and the minute the wind changed directions, the smoke would come in again."

"We were in extreme fire zones until Ontario," she said. "So it just wasn't prudent. Safety first, always. As much as we wanted to continue, it was a really heartbreaking decision for us."

The two officially ended their trip on July 14. Their son, Jesse, picked them up and drove them 13 hours to Whitecourt, Alberta, where they will stay until they resume their trip next year.

Celine said while planning the trip, forest fires wasn't something she had thought of.

"The whole time I was planning this trip, forest fires never dawned on me," she said. "It never crossed my mind, and what an oversight."

And forest fires aren't the only tragedy the pair has endured. Throughout their journey, they have suffered two serious and costly dental emergencies and even had a pack stolen from them one night. Although it hasn't been all good, Celine said the trip has changed her life.

"It's been an amazing experience," she said. "Some people are saying 'well if it wasn't for bad luck, you guys wouldn't have had any luck at all,' and I totally don't see it that way. Stuff happens, it's life. You just go with the flow and you adapt and you persevere and you come out stronger on the other end."

(CP) - People evacuated from a remote village in northwestern Ontario because of a forest fire were allowed to return home Tuesday.</p><p>About 50 people, mostly elderly and those with breathing problems, left Gull Bay First Nation, about 150 kilometres north of Thunder Bay, on Monday night.</p><p>They were moved north to the small community of Armstrong, to escape the smoke from the fire, officials said.</p><p>The fire was burning out of control across 17,000 hectares south of Gull Bay.</p><p>But Dave Jackson, a provincial fire information officer, said Tuesday the wind had shifted and was blowing the smoke away from the village of about 400 people.</p><p>Meanwhile, the fire is burning back on itself, he said. The weather was also co-operating, with cooler temperatures and light rain reported around Gull Bay.</p><p>The village was not directly threatened but the only road linking it and Armstrong to Thunder Bay was closed due to the smoke.</p><p>About 100 firefighters are fighting the flames, with two water bombers and four helicopters.</p><p>In Ontario, 4.2 millimetres of rain fell in April, less than 10 per cent of normal precipitation of 47 millimetres, prompting the ministry to issue a fire ban because of the extremely dry forest conditions.</p><p>The restricted zone covers the area from the Manitoba border to the western shores of Lake Nipigon and includes the city of Thunder Bay. All fires, including campfires, are banned.</p><p>Another forest fire north of Timmins forced the evacuation of several homes on Sunday but firefighters managed to bring it under control.</p><p>Near Kenora, fire crews worked five hours Monday to extinguish a quarter-hectare fire. ATHENS, Greece - The Latest on the fallout from Greece's forest fires (all times local):

10:10 p.m.

Greek authorities say a fifth person injured in last week's forest fire near Athens has died in the hospital, bringing the total death toll to at least 88.

State ERT TV said the woman who succumbed Friday was the 35-year-old mother of a 6-month-old baby that died in the blaze and the wife of a firefighter who helped battle the blaze near the resort area of Mati.

Eleven days after the fire, the exact death toll was still unclear, with figures diverging between coroners and the fire department.

The fire service, which has been issuing the official death toll, put the number of death at 88 on Friday, including two unidentified, unclaimed bodies. One person is still unaccounted for.

___

6:00 p.m.

Greece's public order minister has resigned in the aftermath of last week's deadly forest fires near Athens that killed at least 87 people.

A government statement says Nikos Toskas' resignation has been accepted by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, with whom he met Friday.

The July 23 blaze ravaged the coastal Mati district northeast of Athens, fanned on by strong winds.

___

2:15 p.m.

Greece's environment minister says authorities will start demolishing dozens of illegal constructions in the wider Athens region next week, in a crackdown on illegal building following the country's deadliest forest fire in decades.

Giorgos Stathakis told Greek radio channel 24/7 Friday that authorities would tear down 61 structures, mainly fencing, at sites on beaches, streams and areas earmarked for reforestation in several regions of Attica.

Government officials have blamed illegal construction for contributing to the July 23 disaster, when a fast-moving wildfire swept through a seaside resort near Athens, killing at least 87 people. But criticism has also mounted over how authorities responded to the blaze.

There is also confusion over the exact death toll, with figures diverging between coroners and the fire department.

((Atlantic-Fires))</p><p>Residents of three Atlantic provinces are suffering under a blue haze of smoke.</p><p>It's caused by more than 100 forest fires burning in Quebec.</p><p>The smokey air has reached as far south as Halifax.</p><p>People with breathing problems are advised to stay indoors and avoid exerting themselves.</p><p>The thick smoke is hampering fire-watch efforts in the region.</p><p>Natural Resources fire-detection crews in northern New Brunswick were grounded yesterday and fire tower operators in Nova Scotia reporting poor visibility.</p><p>Fires that broke out in central New Brunswick were quickly brought under control.</p><p>One blaze is out of control near Bay D'Espoir in Newfoundland. She shot back that if soldiers were good enough to help clear snow from the streets of Toronto during last winter's storms, they should be good enough to help fight fires.</p><p>About 150 firefighters continued to fight the blaze Tuesday.</p><p>Several hours of rain in the morning did not eliminate the danger, although a shift in the wind had stabilized the situation by early evening.</p><p>"The town is not being threatened at the moment, no one is in danger," said town councillor Sherman Strong.</p><p>"There's been a shift in the wind and they're using a chemical foam right now on a front that is facing the town."</p><p>Many of the firefighters spent Tuesday dousing everything around the perimetre of the fire in an attempt to keep it from expanding.</p><p>"We've been able to contain it within its present perimetre," said Ivan Downton, a provincial fire officer.</p><p>"We've got pump units set up around the community and on the leading edge of the fire ...We're well-prepared in case the fire springs up again and the community is threatened."</p><p>Four water bombers were working the fire Tuesday, including two planes from Quebec.</p><p>Ontario sent 61,000 metres of hose and 25 tank-pump units.</p><p>Officials gathered Tuesday evening to determine the next move.</p><p>It was not clear when people would be allowed to go back home. One report said the town wouldn't be reopened until at least noon today.</p><p>Many Badger residents registered with the Red Cross in Grand Falls-Windsor, about 30 kilometres away, although most were staying with friends and relatives.</p><p>Much of the forest in the area is tinder dry. Weather in recent weeks has been hot and dry and there was little snowfall over the winter.</p><p>The fire, which was started Saturday by a lightning strike, at one point measured 10 kilometres by four kilometres.</p><p>Premier Brian Tobin said people across Newfoundland must do their part to ensure the hot, dry summer doesn't turn into a major disaster.</p><p>"We shouldn't kid ourselves, it's early in the summer," the premier said as he toured the area.</p><p>"We're dry and we have a big challenge this summer. We're all going to have to pull together to get through it."</p><p>Emergency officials are escorting any resident who wants to retrieve items from their homes, said Strong.</p><p>"Anyone who wants to come back into town is brought under escort if they need to pick up something they forgot," he said. "But other than that, everyone is out."</p><p>The weather forecast for the region is more sunshine, Strong said wearily.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>CANADIAN PRESS; Newfoundland Forest, Resources and Agri-foods Minister Kevin Aylward (left) and Premier Brian Tobin (second from left) meet in Badger, Nfld., with firefighters and officials. (CP) - A state of emergency remained in effect early today after a fire raged through a forest just three kilometres from the heart of this Northern Ontario city.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Timmins fire Chief Lester Cudmore said the fire was all but out by late this morning, but was being watched closely for flare-ups.</p><p>"The fire still isn't under control,'' he said. "When you're talking about a bush fire, it can flare up even when it looks like it's out.''</p><p>Ben Legouffe, information officer for the Ministry of Natural Resources, said he knew right away the fire was serious.</p><p>"It was like a big mushroom cloud and it was crowning - jumping from treetop to treetop - so you could almost see the flames from town,'' Legouffe said Thursday.</p><p>"I knew right away it was time to get to work.''</p><p>The roughly 500 people evacuated from two trailer parks along the nearby Mattagami River were allowed back into their homes today. They were evacuated soon after the fire broke out west of the city late Thusday afternoon.</p><p>Mayor Vic Power declared a state of emergency about two hours later.</p><p>Residents of about 12 homes in the fire's path near Baker Lake have not yet been able to return.</p><p>No serious injuries have been reported and Cudmore said the 200 people battling the fast-burning blaze were able to save all the homes and major buildings in its path.</p><p>But Cudmore said for a while late Thursday, it looked like the flames might engulf the city.</p><p>"We could've had a major disaster on our hands,'' he said. "It could have burned right through the town.''</p><p>Burning along a 200-hectare front and whipped up by high winds, the fire jumped the 120-metre wide Mattagami River and a highway.</p><p>Fire crews could not venture into the bush Thursday because they might have been trapped by winds that quicky spread the fire from tree to tree.</p><p>The smoke was so dense firefighters regularly had to be pulled off the line because they couldn't breathe.</p><p>"It's pretty frightening, for sure,'' said police Insp. Ted O'Connor.</p><p>Three water bombers were brought in to help quell the flames from the air while eight crews from local fire departments and the resources ministry worked on the ground.</p><p>At one point the fire raced along the fence surrounding the Malette sawmill. But as firefighters soaked a $7-million inventory of lumber, the blaze veered away.</p><p>The forest fire was the first of the season for the area but Legouffe said they don't usually burn so close to the city.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5PJ1-SNW1-F105-655D-00000-00Chilliwack reservists arrive home from forest fighting tour2017-09-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:27ZLexisNexisNEWSChilliwack reservists arrive home from forest fighting tourJessica Peters

A group of B.C. reservists, including those from Chilliwack, returned from a forest fighting operation to the Col. Roger St. John Armoury on Korea Rd. last Monday.

The group included about 60 reservists and a 23 vehicle convoy, from across the Lower Mainland, Chilliwack, and Vancouver Island. They were a part of Operation Lentus, fighting the fire at Riske Creek. Other reservists that were fighting the fires headed back to areas in the Interior and northern B.C. They all helped form a significant portion of the 39 Canadian Brigade Group contribution.

The reservists conducted both assistance to law enforcement and forest fire fighting. The majority of the forest fire fighting was in the Riske Creek area, west of Williams Lake. This fire grew to 239,000 HA. The fire fighting started on Aug. 14. Members of both local units of The Royal Westminster Regiment and 39 Combat Engineer Regiment contributed to the operation.

The Royal Westminster Regiment is a Primary Reserve light infantry unit that traces its lineage back to 1863.

Anyone interested in the exciting part-time opportunities that the Royal Westminster Regiment has to offer are welcome to attend an Open House at the Col. St. John OMM, CD Armoury at 5355 Korea Road, Chilliwack on Saturday, Sept. 30 from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. That day, armouries all over the country are holding open houses as part of an Army Reserve recruitment drive.

(CP) - Dry conditions continued Friday to fuel a major forest fire burning 140 kilometres north of Thunder Bay.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire grew from 25 hectares Thursday night to 2,000 hectares Friday afternoon, said the Ministry of Natural Resources.</p><p>"Fires like this don't go out that early," said Bob Johnson, with the forest fire management centre in Thunder Bay.</p><p>"This fire is burning away from us and we anticipate, with the wind change, we will be fighting this for the next day or so," he said Friday.</p><p>Johnson said acres of dead balsam in the area are complicating the fire crews' efforts to extinguish the blaze.</p><p>Firefighters are also having a tough time because there are few lakes or creeks in the area to get their pumps set up, said ministry spokesman Mitch Miller.</p><p>No residents were in the immediate area of the fire but provincial police closed Highway 527 to Armstrong, north of Thunder Bay, due to heavy smoke.</p><p>The ministry said the fire, which began Thursday, was started by people.</p><p>A team of 40 firefighters, six bulldozers, three helicopters and two water bomber airplanes were fighting the blaze.</p><p>Miller said the fire situation won't improve until the region gets a significant rainfall.</p><p>But with no major rain in the forecast for at least five days, he expects things to get worse.</p><p>Until further notice, the ministry has declared a restricted fire zone in a large portion of northwestern Ontario.</p><p>That means all open fires are banned. Apr 30, 2017( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) A few late-season snowflakes flutter over Fort McMurray, their whiteness contrasting against surrounding forests blackened one year ago by the most destructive wildfire in Canadian history. A few late-season snowflakes flutter over Fort McMurray, their whiteness contrasting against surrounding forests blackened one year ago by the most destructive wildfire in Canadian history."You don't know how it feels until you lose it all", says Steven Menard, 53, holding up a charred pair of his grandson's first ice skates, plucked from the rubble of his home.On May 1, 2016, a brushfire in the Canadian oil patch erupted into a huge blaze that over the following two months would engulf nearly 600,000 hectares of the boreal forest and force the evacuation of an entire city of 100,000 people.Menard arrived in Fort McMurray as a teenager four decades ago. Little remains of the Abasand neighborhood where his house once stood."I still cry every day," Menard told AFP, confessing that he worries his nightmarish memories of the wildfires will forever haunt him.

"But," he adds, "Fort McMurray needs builders, not whiners." "We have to keep a positive attitude," he says. With the help of his son-in-law, he has been working day and night since November, rain or shine, to rebuild his house.With a smile, the former industrial equipment salesman says he has lost 42 pounds (19 kg) working on the house. He shows photos of himself on his smartphone with a pudgier face. "It's therapeutic," he says.Leaving the city and relocating was not an option, he said. "I wasn't going to finish the story this way. We'll leave on our terms, not on Mother Nature's terms."That said, he still has no idea what the future holds for him.As winter tiptoes away and yields to spring, several of his former neighbors stop by to check on his progress, and on the rebuilding of their own homes."We're putting back together our neighborhood," Menard says. "This devastated land is going to turn green again."- Hammers and saws - Elsewhere in Fort McMurray, the buzz of electric saws and the blows of hammers ring out, blending into a din hinting at renewal.Despite the best efforts of government officials and residents, however, one year has not been enough to wipe away the sorrow and erase the scars left by the disaster.Oil company employee Bilal Abbas, 38, saw his home destroyed in the side-view mirror of his car as he fled with his daughter and pregnant wife."I would have liked my second daughter to be born here, just like me," he says with a smile.Nearly 100,000 people hastily evacuated the city as it was quickly engulfed in flames, grabbing whatever they could as they fled, embers splashing on the hoods of their vehicles.Melissa Blake, the mayor of Fort McMurray, estimates that one year later 15,000 people have still not returned. Many destroyed homes have not been rebuilt. Oil prices plunged prior to the fire and several companies have since then cut back investment in the oil sands, or quit altogether. Without the promise of a job and a better future, many people are hesitant to return."Many people prefer to take the payout from the insurance, sell their land and resettle elsewhere to avoid the uncertainty in Fort McMurray," said Abbas.All around in the hard-hit Waterways district there are vacant lots that have been cleared of debris. Eight out of 10 homes here were destroyed in the fire.Here and there, wooden frames of new homes under construction point to a rebound. However, it is slow to take off. "These are all for sale," Abbas says of the empty lots. "But nobody is buying."Despite all the uncertainty, he said he returned and is staying in a rented home until he can settle with his insurance company and arrange to have his home rebuilt -- a goal for many that remains up in the air."I want to build my new home. I would like to continue being here in this community. But if I'm going to suffer as a result financially, it's going to be tough for me to rebuild," he said."Even if I'd wanted to go somewhere else, my wife would have never allowed it," he quipped, glancing over at Lina who is playing with their two daughters, aged six years and 10 months."We love this place too much to leave it."

urn:contentItem:5WV3-PH81-JDH1-C3HY-00000-00Green New Deal embraces climate change solutions2019-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:27ZLexisNexisOPINIONGreen New Deal embraces climate change solutions

Globally we are in a climate crisis. We are also in the Anthropocene extinction, the current and ongoing extinction of species as a result of human activity. If we continue to do business as usual we will become extinct. I am not willing to let that happen without a fight, so we need to embrace the Green New Deal.

Climate scientists (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) are sounding the alarm. We must keep global warming below 1.5 C. We are seeing the results of global warming all across the globe, including here in Canada. There were devastating forest fires in B.C. in 2017 and 2018, the forest fire that wiped out parts of Fort McMurray, the flooding in Calgary and much more. Those events will continue to escalate, happening with greater frequency and intensity.

I recently visited a friend in Prince George. She suffered terribly from inhaling forest fire smoke. She is one of many.

Last year I visited Tombstone Territorial Park in the Yukon. We walked beside the North Klondike River. There was ice on the far side that is millions of years old. We watched parts of it calve off into the river. The temperature was 31C. The Arctic is heating up. Researchers describe how warming in the Arctic, which is heating up 2.4 times faster than the Northern Hemisphere average, is triggering a cascade of changes in everything from when plants flower to where fish and other animal populations can be found.

Warmer temperatures have shifted forest and tundra growing seasons, boosted rain and snowfall, increased melting, accelerated glaciers and possibly even increased the number of lightning strikes that could increase the risk of Arctic wildfires in the tundra and boreal forest, clearly a signal of climate warming.

Governments and individuals need to take action. There is plenty we can do.

-invest in and subsidize renewable energy.

-retrofit automobile plants to make electric vehicles (which happily I am seeing more and more of on our roads).

-build more and better public transportation.

All of the jobs created by these can be filled by many people including people who currently work in the oil and gas industry. The government should provide funding and education for them to transition.

Indigenous people have important knowledge about mitigating climate change, and their rights should be upheld as stated in the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP), including the right to Free, Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC), and the 94 Calls to Action from the Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

Affordable housing is another area that can help to mitigate climate change. There is an excellent example, Nanaimo Aboriginal Centre, that is Passive House Certified, which incorporates initiatives and technologies that reduce energy use and operational costs over conventional building standards. https://www.cmhc-schl.gc.ca/en/media-newsroom/news-releases/2018/affordable-homes-indigenous-people-open-nanaimo

The service sector in Canada supports a great number of jobs that are low carbon. The Green New Deal recognizes them and would provide increased funding after years of cuts. Our communities would become stronger and more caring.

The Green New Deal not only tackles the climate crisis. It includes implementing the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and stopping the rise of racism. Now is the time for us to come together as one and give it everything we've got. Thank you in advance for embracing the Green New Deal.

Diana Hardacker,

Chemainus

It's been fairly cool, cloudy and we've had a little bit of rain,'' Purchase said.</p><p>-BODY- "It's managed to knock the fire down for us. The control line held and it's looking really good.''</p><p>The blaze, which covers 1,400 square kilometres, burned five cabins in the popular recreation area north of the territorial capital last week and people were ordered to stay away from the area.</p><p>Three unoccupied cabins burned at Tibbet Lake and two others were destroyed at neighboring lakes.</p><p>The fire also edged to within five kilometres of cabins and lodges around nearby Consolation Lake, 70 kilometres northeast of Yellowknife. Fire crews put in fire retardant lines to save the cabins.</p><p>The fire danger remains high in the North Slave Lake region but a campfire ban has been lifted.</p><p>Purchase said the fire has not grown in size. Firefighters are concentrating on the southern flank, and are working to put out hot spots.</p><p>The fire has cost the territorial government $300,000 a day.</p><p>Officials say they're now between $3 million and $5 million over the $9 million allotted to fight the fire.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Six bulldozers and 50 firefighters defended the hamlet's southern limits Saturday as water bombers hammered back the flames enough for the evacuation order to be lifted later in the afternoon.</p><p>"The fire has been contained to a safe perimeter,'' said Susan Mcmanus, a spokeswoman for Alberta Sustainable Resource Development. "Residents are not at immediate risk.''</p><p>She was hopeful those residents who opted to return would get a more restful sleep Saturday night because the winds that had been fueling the fire Friday night had died down to 5 km/h and some rain had fallen.</p><p>"The fire is generally quiet,'' she said. "We did have scattered brief showers over the fire that were quite helpful.''</p><p>A fireguard has been established around the perimeter of the town and a municipal fire truck waited on standby to protect the buildings in the community. Toker said it was complemented by a rapid fire unit that uses compressed foam to protect the structures in the community.</p><p>Firefighters are also trying to protect another 12 unoccupied summer cottages in the area.</p><p>Chisholm is on the northern boundary of the 120 square kilometre fire that is now under attack from 200 firefighters and a fleet of helicopters, planes and heavy equipment.</p><p>Thirteen residents of Flatbush, about 20 km to the south, remain on evacuation alert, but winds blowing out of the east Saturday have given them some respite.</p><p>"If necessary they will be instructed when it may be time to leave,'' Toker said from the scene as two CL-215 water bombers roared overhead.</p><p>About 30 people evacuated from farms north of Flatbush Friday have been allowed to return to their homes, but remain on evacuation alert, she said.</p><p>"We're dealing with a fire and conditions that could change at a moment's notice,'' she added. "While we're doing good work out here right now, we're taking every precaution. This is the largest fire we've had in Alberta this year.''</p><p>The Chisholm residents had been billeted with friends and family in the neighbouring towns of Smith and Slave Lake.</p><p>Access to the community was blocked Friday night by manned barricades that were lifted about 3 p.m. local time Saturday, said Mcmanus.</p><p>Meanwhile, Transport Canada investigators were able to return on Saturday to the scene of a plane crash that killed two people who had been helping fight another fire Friday.</p><p>RCMP removed the bodies of the unidentified pilot and passenger of a forest fire spotter plane that crashed on the edge of fire burning northeast of Red Earth Creek, but had to evacuate the area when the fire came within a half kilometre.</p><p>The Cessna went down in dense forest in a hilly area.</p><p>Police said smoke had reduced visibility in the area.</p><p>Nearly 500 firefighters continue to fight 18 fires in the province after one of the driest winters in Alberta history. Five fires, including the Chisholm fire, continued to burn out of control Saturday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:56JS-YH11-JBVR-355N-00000-00Last of evacuees from B.C. forest fire to be allowed home, but remain on alert2012-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:27ZLexisNexisNATIONAL,PRAIRIES/BCLast of evacuees from B.C. forest fire to be allowed home, but remain on alertLast of evacuees from B.C. fire allowed backThe Canadian Press

PEACHLAND, B.C. - The last of the evacuees from a forest fire that tore through parts of Peachland, B.C., destroying four houses, were given the all-clear to return to their homes Wednesday, three days after they were forced to flee.

The number of evacuees had been steadily decreasing, from 1,550 on Sunday in the hours after the fire broke out to 258 by Wednesday morning.

Those remaining evacuees, who live in the worst-hit areas of Peachland along the northern edge of the community, were permitted to return as of 5 p.m. Wednesday, the Regional District of Central Okanagan said in an news release.

The fire started Sunday afternoon in a ditch near a park just outside Peachland and quickly spread in high winds.

The fire moved three kilometres in a little more than an hour, eventually covering two square kilometres. Three homes and an abandoned house were destroyed, and the RCMP facilitated efforts to shuttle horses away from ranches in the path of the fire.

There were no injuries, among either people or animals, officials have said.

The regional district said crews were still working to target hot spots in the fire, which was considered 85 per cent contained as of Wednesday morning.

While the evacuation orders have been rescinded, the 1,550 who were ordered to leave are now on an evacuation alert, meaning they should be prepared to leave at a moment's notice.

The Central Okanagan Regional District warned residents to be cautious of hazardous conditions, such as brittle trees that can fall silently or what are known as "easy bake ovens" - underground burning root structures that can be extremely hot and unstable.

Air tankers fighting the fire dropped fire retardant to stop the fire's spread, and some homes and properties were covered in the red substance. One Peachland woman said she was in her garage when her house and yard was splashed with fire retardant.

The regional district said homeowners whose properties were covered in fire retardant should call the local office of ICL Performance Products, which specializes in fire retardant.

Investigators have not yet said what may have caused the fire.

"There is always some <br/>anxiety and confusion over this issue at times like this, and we want to <br/>assure everyone that property insurance policies in force at the time of the <br/>loss will, in fact, respond to the damage." Even if there is no direct loss or <br/>damage to a home or property, homeowners insurance policies may also provide <br/>some coverage for additional living expenses if the policyholder is complying <br/>with a government evacuation order. <br/>    Once people have determined that they have had a loss, they should <br/>contact their broker or agent. If this is not possible, but the customer knows <br/>the company with which they are insured, they may contact the company <br/>directly. If customers have any difficulty contacting their company or company <br/>representative, or have any other insurance-related questions stemming from <br/>the fires, Insurance Bureau of Canada would be pleased to be of assistance. </p><p>The toll-free number for Insurance Bureau of Canada in the Atlantic provinces <br/>is 1-800-565-7189. <br/>    "We realize that this is a time of great distress for those affected by <br/>the fires. Our industry takes its obligations in these situations very <br/>seriously, and we will be doing everything we can to help just as quickly as <br/>possible. We responded following Hurricane Juan last year, and we will be <br/>there again now." <br/>    Insurance Bureau of Canada is the national trade association of the <br/>private property and casualty insurance industry.
