(CP) _ After three days away from their homes, the residents of this isolated northern Alberta community were given some good news Saturday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Crews were able to get the upper hand on a large forest fire that had been threatening their village and the 800 evacuees were allowed to return home.</p><p>Alberta Sustainable Resources credited the light rain that fell in the area as playing a big part in containing the blaze.</p><p>The so-called Wentzle fire has scorched 61 square kilometres of forest on the Little Red River Cree Nation, about 12 kilometres northeast of Fox Lake.</p><p>Residents began leaving their homes on Wednesday when officials feared the blaze may head for the community.</p><p>The evacuation was a hardship for many.</p><p>Fox Lake is about 550 kilometres north of Edmonton and is accessible only by boat or plane.</p><p>Many of the evacuees spoke only Cree and had a difficult time staying at hotels in nearby High Level.</p><p>While one group of people was returning home in northern Alberta, another group was leaving west of Edmonton.</p><p>A brush fire forced the evacuation of about 50 people in a subdivision to the northeast of Spruce Grove.</p><p>Four homes were swallowed up by the blaze, fire officials said.</p><p>Jim Phelan, Parkland County deputy fire chief, said the flames were fuelled by a thick layer of poplar-tree fuzz that blanketed the forest floor.</p><p> It simply burns like gasoline,'' Phelan said. It burns very fast and very hot. It flashes the fire across the forest floor.''</p><p>As of Saturday night, the fire was reported to be about 90 per cent held.</p><p>Ten firefighters had to be treated for heat exhaustion while battling the blaze.</p><p>(Edmonton Sun)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20020615CPCPG2016</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2002</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:462T-BX60-01G6-928C-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="272"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2002 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="15" month="06" year="2002"><dateText>June 15, 2002 Saturday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>ENVIRONMENT; A2</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Manitobans charge forest fire evacuation planning nightmare</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>CP)</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>LEAF RAPIDS, Man.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Rick Wilson was still shaking more than a week after he was forced to drive through the flames that danced across the highway outside here.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"It was so hot in the car, the garbage bags melted to the suitcases in back," said Wilson, one of about 1,800 residents of northern Saskatchewan and Manitoba who had to flee as forest fires threatened their homes last month.</p><p nitf:lede="true">They returned home Friday and Saturday as the blazes finally began to retreat.</p><p>Wilson said disorganization on the part of the Leaf Rapids emergency measures team put him in a life-threatening situation as he left town along with about 1,100 other residents.</p><p>"There was no one monitoring us, nobody telling us to turn back," he said. "By that point, there were flames behind us too. We had no choice but to drive through. My girlfriend was crying."</p><p>It was just the beginning of what some evacuees are calling a planning nightmare at Leaf Rapids, a mining community 700 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg.</p><p>As some residents spent the weekend sifting through the wreckage of 17 burned homes, Wilson had harsh words for town officials.</p><p>He said they did a poor job of communicating evacuation plans to residents, who were forced to flee twice in less than a week.</p><p>But Ernie Epp, co-ordinator of the six-member emergency team, said the group mobilized as soon as lightning set the woods on fire just south of Leaf Rapids on June 18.</p><p>On June 20, word went out by loudspeaker: Get Out. The blaze was less than 10 kilometres away and moving quickly.</p><p>In Ontario, 108 "full response" forest fires and 130 "modified response" fires are being fought, the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre said yesterday.</p><p>"In Ontario, generally speaking, things have cooled down over the last couple of days," operations manager Tom Johnston told The Star's Colin Leslie.</p><p>Elsewhere in Manitoba, 21 of 88 fires were still out of control yesterday, but none threatened communities.</p><p>Sixty-one fires were burning yesterday in Saskatchewan, 13 out of control.</p><p>In the Northwest Territories, 37 fires were burning - nearly all of them out of control.</p><p>Crews were closely monitoring a 1,450-square-kilometre blaze near Wrigley, about 400 kilometres northwest of Yellowknife.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source KELOWNA, B.C. _ As many as ten thousand people were forced from their homes Saturday after a forest fire whipped up by high winds exploded in West Kelowna, B.C.

''We have approximately 4,000 homes evacuated,'' said Kirsten Jones, a spokeswoman for the municipality of West Kelowna.

''We think that's affecting approximately 10,000 people.''

The fire had burned two square kilometres by Saturday evening and a spokeswoman for the B.C. forest fire service couldn't predict when it would be under control.

''Crews will continue to work through the night,'' said Elise Riedlinger. ''They're definitely going to be working as hard as they can.''

Three houses were incinerated.

Forestry crews were using six helicopters and eight water bombers to attack the fire from the air, but the aircraft were forced to suspend operations due to darkness, Riedlinger said.

There were 45 provincial firefighters on the ground, backed by the resources of local fire departments in the Kelowna-area. The fire was about two square kilometres before midnight.

''The wind is so bad, you know,'' said Bettyann Barton. You just don't know where it's going to go.''

''Very scary, very scary.''

She said everyone is holding their breath in hopes the devastating fires of 2003 don't repeat themselves.

International Trade Minister Stockwell Day represents the west Kelowna constituency where the fire is raging and he was getting briefings from emergency crews on Saturday.

Day said the highway leading out of the area was jammed with people taking pictures and trying to leave.

Hotels in Kelowna and the surrounding area were fully booked.

The large Gorman Brothers sawmill, with stacks of stored lumber, is also threatened and the local Holiday Inn has been evacuated.

''I can see the flames, and the winds are very strong,'' Day said. ''The sun was blotted out for quite a while earlier in the afternoon. It was just a red ball.''

Day said there was a wisp of smoke at 3 p.m. and within 20 minutes, the fire was spreading rapidly.

''The helicopters and bomber crews responded in an incredibly fast time but the winds are so strong it's pushing this fire along. It's jumped the highway and caused another neighbourhood to be evacuated.''

Joe Ryan lives across Okanagan Lake from the fire scene, and he said ash was falling onto his deck and the air was choked with smoke.

Ryan said his family was coming home from a vacation in the Vancouver area when his daughter saw the fire.

''My daughter yelled out, 'Daddy, Daddy, there's smoke,' and I could see flames.''

It's unclear how the fire started Saturday afternoon near the residential subdivision of Glenrosa in the B.C. Interior city.

''We've been expecting this, but there's been no lightening so we don't know what started this,'' Barton said.

''Probably humans. We've had no storms, no lightening. What else could it be?''

B.C.'s Okanagan region, with its dry climate, is no stranger to forest fires and Kelowna has felt their wrath before.

In 2003, lightening strikes triggered a fire that scorched 250 square kilometres, destroyed more than 200 homes and caused millions of dollars in property damage.

An evacuation order affected up to 45,000 people and it took two weeks for firefighters to conquer what was the most costly fire the area has ever seen.

''For all of us who lived through the last one, this is just a very sick feeling of deja vu in the pits of our stomachs,'' Day said.

''This one, from its beginning, has moved much faster than the one in 2003.''

Ryan said his home was evacuated during the 2003 fires.

''Having gone through it, it's just a very, very surreal feeling and your heart just goes out to these people.''

Kelowna resident Merl Fichtner said his father is one of the many people who must leave the area.

''He's pretty shook up,'' Fichtner said.

''He was looking immediately west and he could see and hear houses exploding on the hillside.''

Although only a small percentage of the 4,000 homes under evacuation were directly threatened by the fire, memories of the 2003 blaze prompted officials to take every precaution, Jones said.

''It is such an unpredictable fire at this point that we're not taking any chances,'' she said.

''Anyone who was in 2003, it's a very familiar sight.''

An arena about 10 kilometres away has been converted into a reception centre for those affected by the evacuation.

There was no way to predict how long people will be away from their homes, Jones said.

''A few people will be sleeping on a gym floor (Saturday night).''

urn:contentItem:5XTC-0NW1-JDH1-C1WV-00000-00Canadians give up Christmas to fight Aussie wildfires2019-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:27ZLexisNexisCANADA / WORLDPg. A8Canadians give up Christmas to fight Aussie wildfiresThe Canadian Press

Sixty-nine Canadians are giving up their holidays at home to join the battle for the first time against the deadly wildfires devastating vast tracts of several Australian states.

The Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre says a contingent of 21 highly trained staff from a variety of agencies left Canada on Dec. 3, for a 38-day deployment in New South Wales after the centre received an official request for assistance.

On Dec. 19 a second group of 30 Canadians was sent in for a 38-day deployment in the fire zone, and a further 18 are leaving on Dec. 30 for about a month.

Kim Connors, the executive director of the Winnipeg based CIFFC, says that Canada has called on Australian firefighters four times since 2015, and the "agreements are reciprocal in nature so it was the first time that Australia has needed help from Canada."

"Our Canadian firefighters and their families have volunteered their time to be away for the holidays, which is different for the northern hemisphere to be dealing with wildland fires over Christmas and New Year's so we're very proud of them for doing that," he said in an interview.

The CIFFC says crews from Newfoundland and Labrador, Quebec, Yukon, Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and B.C. are assisting with a variety of tasks including roles in command and aviation.

urn:contentItem:5GB3-3TH1-DY9S-T0G2-00000-00Scorching temperatures prompt Spain, Portugal to issue health alerts, forest fire warnings2015-06-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:27ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALScorching temperatures prompt Spain, Portugal to issue health alerts, forest fire warningsSpain, Portugal issue health alerts amid scorching tempsThe Associated Press

LISBON, Portugal - Spain and Portugal both issued weather alerts Monday, advising residents to take extra care as temperatures soared above 40 C (104 F) in some southern areas.

The Iberian Peninsula was sweltering in a heat wave brought on by a mass of hot air flowing north from Africa to Europe in recent days, though recorded temperatures fell shy of the day's forecast of a maximum 44 C (111.2 F).

With the temperature in Cordoba hitting 41 degrees Celsius (105.8 Fahrenheit), Spanish authorities placed the southern city on alert due to "extreme risks" from the heat. People across the southern half of Spain flocked to beaches, swimming pools and fountains.

In Portugal, a high of 37 C (98.6 F) was recorded in the eastern city of Beja, while the capital, Lisbon, sweltered in 35 C (95 F) heat. Portugal's General Directorate for Health recommended staying out of the sun between 11 a.m. and 5 p.m.

Iberia is forecast to start cooling down on Tuesday when the heat wave is due to move into northern Europe, including the United Kingdom.

Portuguese authorities also warned of a high risk of forest fires in wooded areas of central and northern Portugal.

Official statistics show that after an uncommonly dry winter and spring, almost 54 per cent of the Portuguese mainland was enduring extreme or severe drought at the end of May. With little rainfall in June, that percentage is expected to rise.

(CP) - Rick Wilson was still shaking more than a week after he was forced to drive through the flames that danced across the highway outside here.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"It was so hot in the car, the garbage bags melted to the suitcases in back," said Wilson, one of about 1,800 residents of northern Saskatchewan and Manitoba who had to flee as forest fires threatened their homes last month.</p><p>They returned home Friday and Saturday as the blazes finally began to retreat.</p><p>Wilson said disorganization on the part of the Leaf Rapids emergency measures team put him in a life-threatening situation as he left town along with about 1,100 other residents.</p><p>"There was no one monitoring us, nobody telling us to turn back," he said. "By that point, there were flames behind us too. We had no choice but to drive through. My girlfriend was crying."</p><p>It was just the beginning of what some evacuees are calling a planning nightmare at Leaf Rapids, a mining community 700 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg.</p><p>As some residents spent the weekend sifting through the wreckage of 17 burned homes, Wilson had harsh words for town officials.</p><p>He said they did a poor job of communicating evacuation plans to residents, who were forced to flee twice in less than a week.</p><p>But Ernie Epp, co-ordinator of the six-member emergency team, said the group mobilized as soon as lightning set the woods on fire just south of Leaf Rapids on June 18.</p><p>On June 20, word went out by loudspeaker: Get Out. The blaze was less than 10 kilometres away and moving quickly.</p><p>In Ontario, 108 "full response" forest fires and 130 "modified response" fires are being fought, the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre said yesterday.</p><p>"In Ontario, generally speaking, things have cooled down over the last couple of days," operations manager Tom Johnston told The Star's Colin Leslie.</p><p>Elsewhere in Manitoba, 21 of 88 fires were still out of control yesterday, but none threatened communities.</p><p>Sixty-one fires were burning yesterday in Saskatchewan, 13 out of control.</p><p>In the Northwest Territories, 37 fires were burning - nearly all of them out of control.</p><p>Crews were closely monitoring a 1,450-square-kilometre blaze near Wrigley, about 400 kilometres northwest of Yellowknife.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source TORONTO, ONTARIO--(Marketwire - May 24, 2012) - Lake Shore Gold Corp. (TSX:LSG)(NYSE MKT:LSG)(NYSEAmex:LSG) ("Lake Shore Gold" or the "Company") today announced that as a result of high winds and smoke from a forest fire approximately 15 kilometres southwest of the Timmins West Mine, operations at the mine have been temporarily suspended. The Company also announced that it has suspended all surface exploration work. Production from the Company's milling facility and mining operations at the Bell Creek Mine, both located on the east side of Timmins, are not affected by the forest fire. The Company currently has a stockpile of 16,000 tonnes of ore available for processing at the mill, representing approximately eight days of production, with another 6,000 tonnes of ore on surface at the Timmins West Mine and 35,000 tonnes of low-grade material also stockpiled at the mill.

Tony Makuch, President and CEO of Lake Shore Gold, commented: "Nothing is more important than the health and safety of our people and with the temporary suspension of operations at Timmins West Mine we have taken the steps necessary to ensure that no one is at risk. In terms of production, with the large stockpile we have at the mill we expect there to be no impact on our processing activities. Our production guidance for the second quarter and full year 2012 remain unchanged. We are very pleased with the level of professionalism and cooperation we are receiving from the Ontario Provincial Police, City of Timmins and Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and believe that everything is being done to alleviate the situation as quickly as possible."

About Lake Shore Gold

Lake Shore Gold is a gold mining company that is in production and pursuing rapid growth through the successful exploration, development and operation of three wholly owned, multi-million ounce gold complexes in the Timmins Gold Camp. The Company is in commercial production at both the Timmins West and Bell Creek mines, with material being delivered for processing to the Bell Creek Mill. A 50% mill expansion, to 3,000 tonnes per day is progressing and is targeted for completion by late 2012. The Company continues to have an active drilling program aimed at supporting current operations and evaluating high-priority exploration targets around the Timmins Camp. The Company's common shares trade on the TSX and NYSE MKT under the symbol LSG.

urn:contentItem:5VTH-V8F1-DY9S-T0RF-00000-00Firefighters extinguish most of South Korean forest blaze2019-04-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:27ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALFirefighters extinguish most of South Korean forest blazeFirefighters extinguish most of South Korean forest blazeJung-Yoon Kim And Kim Tong-HyungThe Associated Press

SEOUL, Korea, Republic Of - Firefighters managed to extinguish most of a massive forest fire that ripped through South Korea's mountainous northern coast Friday, destroying 135 homes and forcing more than 4,000 to flee the region that hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics.

One person was killed by what government officials said was possibly the country's biggest forest fire ever. Another person was fatally struck by an object blown over by the high winds fanning the flames.

The Ministry of the Interior and Safety said fires in in the county of Goseong and nearby coastal city of Sokcho were fully extinguished. Strong winds also carried the blaze to the towns of Gangneung and Inje, but the ministry said fires in those areas were 70 to 80% extinguished.

The fire likely started Thursday night from a transformer spark near a resort in Goseong and then spread to the mountains, according to Choi Jin-ho, a fire captain at Gangwon Fire Headquarters. Gangwon province governs the Olympic host city of Pyeongchang and is about 210 kilometres (130 miles) northeast of Seoul.

Videos posted to social media in South Korea showed tall flames rising from large areas of forest, the air filled with embers and debris as cars drove by the raging fire. News photos showed a burnt-out bus, fire engulfing a hill, and residents evacuating apartment complexes and filing into gyms.

The region is close to the border with North Korea. South Korea's Unification Ministry said Friday it plans to inform North Korea of details about the forest fires.

The ministry said 135 homes and more than 100 other buildings were burned. About 525 hectares (2 square miles) of forest was estimated to have been destroyed.

About 60 helicopters, 300 vehicles and 17,700 firefighting personnel were being deployed, the ministry said. The fire also caused blackouts in Goseong, disruptions in telecommunications and internet services, a temporary shutdown of a highway, and delays in train services from Gangneung to Seoul.

Authorities said a 60-year-old man died because of the fire, and a woman in her 70s died after being hit by wide-angle mirror on a road that fell because of strong winds. Eleven people were treated for injuries. The government didn't comment on the nature of the injuries or how many were serious.

The office of South Korean President Moon Jae-in said he called for all available resources to be deployed.

The fire hasn't threatened the Olympic sports facilities, including the main venues in Pyeongchang, the alpine centre in Jeongseon, and the skating centres in seaside Gangneung.

urn:contentItem:7VKR-D890-Y9NS-W4SG-00000-00Halifax councillor surprised by randomness of destruction caused by forest fire2009-05-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:27ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSHalifax councillor surprised by randomness of destruction caused by forest fireJOHN LEWANDOWSKICP

HALIFAX _ For councillor Linda Mosher there's a surreal quality to the fire-blackened landscape, the after effect of a large forest fire, under control but not yet totally tamed, in the Ferguson's Cove area on the edge of Halifax.

It is part of the district she represents at city hall.

Most of the area's 1,100 residents evacuated at the height of the emergency returned to their homes late Friday while fire officials and police remained on scene keeping a close watch on hotspots for any potential flareups.

''It's a minor miracle that no one was hurt,'' said Mosher early Saturday after a scant few hours of sleep.

But, she conceded that what struck her most, given the intensity of the flames and smoke that covered almost eight square kilometres at the fire's height, is the randomness of the destruction.

Having toured the hardest hit area late Friday with fire officials and some of the people who lost their homes Mosher said she was having difficulty reconciling what she saw.

''Some properties weren't touched and there's still a lot of greenery around them but travel in a little further and it's shocking,'' she said.

''I was looking at two brightly coloured adirondack chairs, untouched by flames, set out on the side of a small hill to take advantage of the view of Halifax Harbour. Above them the house was burned to the ground.''

A little further down the road there's a beautiful gazebo sitting on the side of one property and a garage with a shiny new truck and a street hockey net undamaged on the other.

In between there's nothing more than a pile of charred rubble, all that's left of the house that musician and recording artist Brett Ryan and his family fled on Thursday afternoon, just as flames were reaching their back porch.

Ryan said although they've lost almost everything the fire has helped he and his wife Lara understand what's important.

''This is all just stuff. We don't need it. In the end the most important thing is our family. It sounds hokey but in the end it rings pretty true.''

Ryan lost a couple of antique cars that he and his father were working on and many of his guitars.

But the one that matters most, a 1956 Gibson Jumbo that he got from his Dad, was spared.

''Lennie Gallant is doing a record at our studio right now and he asked if he could borrow it so I said 'Sure, no problem.'''

Ryan and his family have moved into his parents' home until they figure out what the future holds.

For now he said it's a matter of making sure that life is as normal as possible for his three children.

''My son loves hockey and we're heading out to one of his spring league games this afternoon,'' he said.

His son's hockey gear, a wedding ring and family photos were all he was able to grab before fleeing the house.

In all, the fire destroyed eight homes and damaged several others to varying degrees after it grew from a small brush fire to an inferno stretching over hundreds of hectares and fanned by strong winds late Thursday.

The more than 100 firefighters and five helicopters enlisted to battle the blaze were pulled out Friday afternoon as light rain became a deluge.

As many as 500 people have been forced<br/>from their homes overnight as a wall of flames advances on a<br/>heavily populated subdivision. Firefighters are scrambling to<br/>contain the fire, but shifting winds and tinder dry conditions are<br/>fuelling the danger. CTV's Tom Walters has the latest.</p><p>TOM WALTERS [Reporter]: Summer begins with a fire in the forest.<br/>A five kilometer wall of flame in the woods near Halifax. Greg<br/>Richardson and Ron Falkehnam watch as it creeps toward their<br/>street.</p><p>RON FALKENHAM [Resident]: It's close to home.</p><p>WALTERS: Where is your house.</p><p>FALKENHAM: Just down the hill here.</p><p>GREG RICHARDSON [Resident]: It's moving pretty quickly right now.</p><p>WALTERS: Have you been asked to leave?</p><p>RICHARDSON: Yeah. We're just packed up here and we're just about<br/>ready to leave.</p><p>WALTERS: And then it's time. In this neighbourhood people take<br/>just what is most precious and head out leaving empty streets and<br/>empty driveways and empty homes in the shadow of the blaze. In the<br/>smoky haze that hangs over nearby lakes, helicopters pick up<br/>buckets of water to drop on the fire. The battle from the air<br/>matched by the work of ,2500 firefighters on the ground. And they<br/>are making a dent.</p><p>TERRY BOURGEOIS [Halifax Fire Department]: It's getting smaller.<br/>but it's kind of looped around on itself a couple of times.</p><p>WALTERS: As the day ends, the fire has been pressed back enough<br/>that authorities can let some people return to their homes. They<br/>must make plans for the others.</p><p>JOHN O'BRIEN [Halifax City Official]: Well we're looking for a<br/>center that will accommodate over 500 people.</p><p>WALTERS: And as a few gather in emergency shelters, many more<br/>will follow for a long and worry filled night away from their<br/>homes. Tom Walters, CTV News, Halifax.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CTV2000</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:40JC-6G20-00RJ-F494-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">211506</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="317"/><timeReceived>23:00:00 - 23:30:00 Eastern Time</timeReceived><publicationInfo><publicationName>CTV Television, Inc.</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2000 CTV Television, Inc.</copyright><publicationDate month="06" day="21" year="2000"><dateText>June 21, 2000</dateText></publicationDate></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="subject"><classificationItem score="90"><classCode>STX000726</classCode><className>FIRES</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="90"><classCode>STX001009</classCode><className>FOREST FIRES</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="90"><classCode>ST000DOX0</classCode><className>WILDFIRES</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="64"><classCode>ST0008X9I</classCode><className>CITY GOVERNMENT</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="64"><classCode>N922160CC</classCode><className>FIRE DEPARTMENTS</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="51"><classCode>STX001035</classCode><className>LAKES</className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="industry"><classificationItem score="51"><classCode>STX002247</classCode><className>HELICOPTERS</className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup></metadata></articleDoc></content></entry>

(AP) _ The U.S. Forest Service has released video footage of two people who may have information about a deadly forest fire that killed four firefighters in 2001.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The video footage of a man and woman was obtained during the investigation.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AP</p></bodyText></section><p>The two people are considered potential witnesses and are not suspects, said Ron Pugh, an assistant special agent with the service.</p><p>"They are people who may be able to tell us something about how the fire started, and that would help us in our ongoing investigation,'' Pugh said in a news release.</p><p>Four Washington state firefighters died in the Thirtymile Fire in the Okanogan National Forest on July 10, 2001.</p><p>Tom Craven, 30, of Ellensburg, and Yakima firefighters Devin Weaver, 21, Karen FitzPatrick, 18 and Jessica Johnson, 19, died in the Chewuch River Canyon north of Winthrop.</p><p>An investigation into the fire concluded that commanders broke all 10 of the agency's standard safety rules.</p><p>The mistakes left firefighters cut off from their only escape route in a dead-end canyon with fire fast approaching.</p><p>The cause of the fire was determined to be an unattended cooking fire, Pugh said.</p><p>"We have not forgotten the Thirtymile Fire or the employees who died or were injured at that time,'' he said.</p><p>"Our law enforcement staff would like to talk with these two individuals because they may have information that will help.''</p><p>The service would not say how it came upon the video footage.</p><p>Agency officials contacted local, county and regional law enforcement agencies, local businesses and the families of the fallen firefighters to try to identify the two individuals before going public with the video footage.</p><p>The families of the four fallen firefighters all filed wrongful-death claims against the service last year. Attorneys for the families said the government did not respond to those claims, leaving them free to file lawsuits.</p><p>An attorney for Craven's widow, Evelyn Craven, said she plans to file a wrongful-death lawsuit against the service in federal court soon.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) _ A northeastern Saskatchewan community remained on emergency alert Thursday as a stubborn forest fire smoldered on its outskirts.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Mayor Glen Day said fire crews were still putting out hot spots and controlling flare-ups around Nipawin, more than three days after the blaze broke out.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>We are still having flare-ups and, depending on wind and weather conditions, it still has the potential to pick up significantly,'' Day said. They get an area that they think is out and then, all of a sudden, it flares back up again.''</p><p>Fire crews and town officials will review the emergency status daily to determine when it can be lifted, he said.</p><p>Day is hoping the fire will be out by this Victoria Day long weekend when fisherman flock to the area.</p><p> The lakes next door are some of the few lakes that are ice free,'' Day said. People will be coming here, there's no doubt about that, despite the fire.''</p><p>The fire forced about 65 people from their homes Tuesday, including about 24 from a seniors' residence.</p><p>The evacuation order was lifted late Wednesday, but only about half of the people chose to return.</p><p> There still is smoke drifting around and some of them have respiratory problems so they don't want to be around,'' Day said.</p><p>Saskatchewan Premier Lorne Calvert toured the fire area Thursday and pledged provincial help with the cost of water bombers used to fight the fire.</p><p> Here we have had a state of emergency appropriately declared,'' Calvert said.</p><p> In this circumstance I have indicated to the mayor and council that, as a province, we will be prepared to cost-share on the air support.''</p><p>The fire was ignited by a blaze that destroyed Newfield Seeds earlier in the week.</p><p>Dry conditions hampered crews trying to bringing the blaze under control and two water bombers were called in to help with the fight.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
